A few blocks from my house there is a group of stores with some offices on the second floors. Apparently there is a Planned Parenthood office in the complex because a group of anti-abortion protestors were there the other day. I didn't know that before then. I wondered what they hoped to accomplish by their protest so I asked them. One woman said she hoped to discourage women from considering abortion. 
 
 I didn't think of it at the time, but Planned Parenthood does a lot more than abortion services. I wonder if the protests might also dissuade a young woman who was seeking contraceptive services from going into that office as well. If this were the case, the abortion protests would accomplish the opposite of their goal. They potentially could have increased the chances of an unwanted pregnancy by discouraging contraceptive use. In turn, this might increase the chances of an abortion. I wonder if anti-abortion folks ever consider that?

 The viable replacement to abortion exists now, and always has existed. It's called adoption. Today there's a 3 to 5 year waiting period for a standard adoption. And even a 2 year waiting period if one goes through a private agency and has to buy their baby. This article explains it better than I can and discusses how it works in other Countries where Americans go to adopt children because they just aren't available here. So pro-lifers have an optional solution, it's just that pro-abortionists reject it in favor of the convenience of infanticide. Here's an excerpt.
 When Faith Allen wanted to adopt a baby, she turned to the yellow pages. Allen, 37, a professional writer from North Carolina in the US, had suffered many painful years of infertility and in 1999 decided to adopt.
 
 A friend recommended a nearby adoption agency but the three- to five-year waiting period seemed much too long to wait. That's when Allen decided to turn to the phone book.
 
 "I wound up stumbling upon a wonderful agency," said Allen who admits that she "got lucky" with her find.
 
 Nearly two years and $12,000 (E8,000) later, Allen's dearest wish was finally realised when she became a mother to a little baby boy named Nicholas.
 
 When news of his birth broke, Allen and her husband packed their car and drove six hours from North Carolina to Georgia. For two days they waited anxiously in a friend's house until the baby's mother signed the papers. Three days after his birth, they had Nicholas in their arms.
 http://www.independent.ie/lifestyle/parenting/so-you-want-to-adopt-a-baby-1255662.html

Right, abortion..like anything..will not go away and making abortion illegal won't make the externalities go away. I don't go by the policy that you do a wrong to make a right. 
 
 
 
 
Neither. You'd do something to change their life, get them into a better school, foster home something.
Really!? And you can't do this for the unborn when born because what? Costs? It would cost a lot to do what you wish as well. You can't throw in enough money to solve the problem of crime.
 
 
But then that raises the issue of costs. I generally support the legality of abortion for several reasons:
 
 1) Alternatives suck
 2) Personal liberty
 3) Lowers welfare
 4) Lowers crime 
1)Adoption is better than killing someone 2)No one has the liberty to kill an innocent person..why should it be different if you aren't born 3)not shown to be true 4)not shown to be true
 
 Those reasons are terrible. Seriously, you could use those same reasons to support slavery.
obvious_child

You can find a correlation between firearm training and firearm accidents. You can't find a correlation between proper sex education and the abortion rate. Furthermore, one is direct while the other is indirect. I think it is you who needs to provide the numbers..not I.

 
 Then how you explain Europe's low abortion rates when they have many factors that should increase abortion rates? 
 
 It appears that the only noticeable difference is education.
 
 
I disagree that morality is subjective and I don't think emotional arguments are a bad thing.

 
 There may be an absolute morality, but none of us are God(s) therefore we can't be sure what it is. Therefore we all apply our own interpretation of morality and thus make it subjective. 
 
 
In fact, as Another Opinion often states, they are often used in terms of realizing rights for others. But again, if you can't use science or economics as a basis for a moral decision. Economic morality was a common argument for slavery in the 1800s by the way.

 
 Which brings up another question: Should this be a moral decision? Japan and China have very different attitudes. Much of the Western world doesn't treat abortion like we do. So should this be a moral decision? And I'm not applying economic morality. In fact if you note, I stripped morality out entirely. 
 
 
Not only have a seen the articles written by Levitt but I have read many (not sure about all) of the rebuttals and updates. If this were any other topic the conclusion would have been laughed at. In any event, even if true I would still say it has no weight because killing to lower crime is idiotic in my opinion. I don't support eugenic arguments.

 
 So I take it you're against the death penalty as well? I suppose that's not true as the Death Penalty hasn't been shown to be an actual deterrent. I'm not sure I agree with the rebuttals. Crack seriously? That's the major claim against him? The biggest problem I see with Levitt is using correlation statistics. If I he can fix that (which he appears he has claimed to) there might still be something here. 
 
 
Right, abortion..like anything..will not go away and making abortion illegal won't make the externalities go away. I don't go by the policy that you do a wrong to make a right.

 
 Huh? How is that do a wrong to make a right? If as you state, it's not going away, why shouldn't we take advantage of its externalities? 
 
 
Really!? And you can't do this for the unborn when born because what? Costs? It would cost a lot to do what you wish as well. You can't throw in enough money to solve the problem of crime.

 
 Actually you can. It's called education. People should not be having kids until they are ready. But until we actually have proper sex education...
 
 
1)Adoption is better than killing someone

 
 Not to everyone. And it ignores Opportunity costs.
 
 
2)No one has the liberty to kill an innocent person..why should it be different if you aren't born

 
 The state has done it at least 100 times. And then you run into the problem of who's liberty comes first. 
 
 
3)not shown to be true 4)not shown to be true

 
 Jumping the gun aren't we? If Levitt's new calculations are true, then both are still true, just smaller.
 
 
Those reasons are terrible. Seriously, you could use those same reasons to support slavery.

 
 Huh? How?
Colonel Ingus

In fact some of the most ardent anti-abortion people I've met are also some of the most ardent anti-comprehensive sexual education people as well. 

 Amazing how regularly they shoot themselves in the foot isn't it? ;)
electrolyte

In fact some of the most ardent anti-abortion people I've met are also some of the most ardent anti-comprehensive sexual education people as well.

 
Amazing how regularly they shoot themselves in the foot isn't it? ;)

 Chalk it up to the fact that -- although not all the time -- a good part of the time, the same people are pretty anti-anything education. We shouldn't expect them to argue positions that make sense.
Shooterandproud

You call them pro-life protesters, I call them walking paintball targets.
 
 
 Not that I would really shoot them, its just hard to supress the urge sometimes.
